Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If blood is multiplied, then pulverize over it zeji ground or gall-stones, and similar ones from poppy seeds: until the blood is cut off.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or pulverized almonds (fabarum) without their shells are placed on the site and left until the beans stick to the place, for blood is cut off.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And it is necessary that if a repetition of Sanguisugarum (a sugar extract from the sap of the blood-leaf plant) is needed, it should be changed when possible.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 But if Sanguisuga (leeches) are forbidden from being hung up, then clean the site with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or insert an aculeus (a pointed instrument or needle) into the sites until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then place them, for they themselves will stick immediately when they sense something from the blood.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 Whenever you want them to fall (off), pulverize something from ground aloes, salt or ashes over them, and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Beginning of the Third Book of Albucasis's Surgery.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 Universal Discourse on Restoration, Dislocation, and Treatment of Torsions and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This Chapter is also frequently necessary in the art of Medicine and it is restoration for fractures and dislocations occurring in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know ye, O sons, that foolish doctors and the common people boast about this Chapter, and those who have never looked at an ancient book or read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And for this reason, this method has been deprived of learned men in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never used it in a good way, nor have I acquired that from it except for the length of reading ancient books and my diligence in understanding them until I extracted the knowledge of that method from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I attach myself to experiment and study throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 And now I have described for you the entire content of that chapter containing my knowledge; and above what my experiment exceeded, after abbreviating it for you, and freeing it from occupation with elongation, and abbreviating it to its end of abbreviation, and showing it at its end of declination: and I have formed in it many forms of instruments that are administered within it, since it is due to the addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and collections of fractures of bones from those whose separation is necessary before we begin the reminder of broken members, and of various kinds, if of each one separately.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this chapter the main points and headings, to which the craftsman must be directed first regarding their truth: namely, that you and those who are ready should know or learn this noble art from each other.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 Therefore, I say that when a fracture or dislocation or twist or accident happens to someone, then it is necessary to rush at first to bleed him and free him, or both simultaneously: unless something prevents it, such as weakness of strength; or he who it has happened to is a child or an old man decrepitus; or it is a time of intense heat or intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then he should be content with his food, cold vegetables, beans and cabbage: and forbid wine, coarse meats, and to be filled from foods and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until when you are secure from a hot apoplectic attack, and do not fear the flow of matter to the limb: then let the sick person return to his own regimen first with which his custom has been accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When therefore the broken bone begins to heal, then it is necessary that the sick person be fed with nourishing foods in abundance, thick, heavy, containing viscosity: such as food made from cooked wheat with water, rice, and heads, and feet, and innards of cows, and eggs, and fresh fish; and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 When this regimen is followed, the healing of the fracture happens more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in the first old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be joined and consolidated according to their nature always, because of the drying up of their limbs; and they are consolidated and joined only at the end of the softness, such as the bones of small boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 However, nature connects something similar to a glue on every part of the broken bone, in which there is thickness, by which it adheres and tightens it until they are consolidated to each other, and bound together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prohibit something from its operations; and for this reason, it is necessary that you give nourishment to the sick with foods that have thickness, viscosity, and heaviness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know that the kinds of fractures are various, according to the diversity of the limbs; because the fracture of the leg is different from the fracture of the bone of the head; and the fracture of the bone of the chest is different from the fracture of the bone of the back; and all other limbs are different from each other in this way; and I come with a reminder of every kind of fracture exposed in its own chapter distinguished from others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of bone fracture are also diversified within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Because the fracture is arched, stars also happen in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture is along the length of the bone; and there are fractures called stars, that is, points, and additions protruding, like in a reed when it is cut with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not protruding; and there is the fracture with wound and dislocation at the head; and there is the small crack fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every kind has a skill, or its own tool for restoration, according to what its memory comes up, distinguished in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which the bone fracture is known, there is its twist and its protrusion; and its appearance to the sense and its sound when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore there is no twist appearing nor sound under your touch when you touch the bone with movement, nor does a weak great pain appear; then there is no fracture there, indeed it is possible that there is a twist or small crack; therefore do not move it with your hand and compression at all, but put medicines over it whose memory comes up after some time; then tie a string around it with a fine ligation.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that the place becomes arched and is split into two, but stars appear in it; however, all parts should be removed from each other; then you must begin to start at your hour for its correction, aligning it before a hot abscess appears on it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If however a hot abscess appears on it, then leave it for some days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then align it according to whatever method possible with gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration and its equality is easier than the bone, where complications occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tie it up, according to what comes to your recollection of it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If there are complications in the bone, then an extension of this broken member is necessary from both sides, whether it be a hand or foot; or with your hand if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 And let your position be such when you place the member on a level surface according to its natural shape, until the parts of the broken member are extended; then try to bring back all additions with every effort and in whatever way possible at their places; and beware lest, by your operation, pain or injury occurs, nor harm; and try with your strength, to apply one of two bones together with its companion, according to better shapes.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 And it is necessary that you probe it at that time with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see anything different there, correct it and make it equal by the amount of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of violent stretching and strong compressions, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For they often cause an abscess to occur due to their operation or a contraction in the member; as we have seen this happens many times from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then attach after the equality and suitable operation, and compression, relaxation, and peace of that member; and warn the weak person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And make him take care not to move it during his waking hours and sleep, during its rotation, its stirring, and during its exertions, and all his movements with the last of his strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And so that it may be avoided, let there not be a position of a limb with which follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 Whenever there is pain or injury while in the position of a limb, then it must be moved to another position in which no pain is felt.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And see that its position is equal and straight, so that there will not be a twisting in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 The quality of the constriction of the broken member, as I have told.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that fractured members are differentiated according to their size and form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those that are small, such as the arm, finger, fleshy part of the ear, and similar to these, then it is necessary that the bandage be made of soft, fine fabric.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 Those that are large, such as the hip and leg, it is necessary that there be a wide, firm bandage around them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a broad ligament binds a large member and compresses it from all sides with equal constriction, so that no spot remains inside of it.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then begin after your evacuation to place a suitable poultice on it at the soft spot of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wrap the bandage around the location of the fracture itself with three or four wrappings, according to what the member deserves; and bind your hand slightly with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go to the upper part from the location of the fracture and bind it less than your previous constriction, with which you bound the fractured place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then extend yourself and the bandage slightly away from the location of the fracture and gradually soften the constriction until you gather much from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another poultice, and wrap it again over the fracture with bandages.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Advance with subsidence towards the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your operation be in the constriction of subsidence, and softening it, as we said in the first subsidence above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the subsidences from soft sponge or cloth, which corresponds to the crookedness of the fracture, if there is crookedness in it; and if not, do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then subside upon another piece of meat above it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place equal stars (stitches) well made immediately on top of these subsidences, if there is no swelling or warm abscess in the area.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is swelling or abscess in it; then place upon it what sits on the abscess and remove the swelling; and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then bind over these with stitches.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 Let the stitches be half of a thick reed, smooth and well formed; or let them be from wood where sieves are made, which are made of pine or oak, or calingi: and let the width of each stitch be according to this shape and this same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, it is necessary that the stitch which is placed upon the swollen part be slightly thicker and wider than the other stitches; and the length of the stitch should be according to what is suitable for the limb in size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind over the stitches with another piece of linen, following the first constriction.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind over with threads well, as we said about the constriction; and let your constriction be over the fracture place more; and the farther it extends from the fracture, the less the constriction should be.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 It is necessary that the threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and they should be from soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 If threads are thick, as I have seen in the operation of stupid people putting their threads twisted from the cord of flax, it is a great mistake: because the constriction falls out with them beyond its quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 Fine threads do not agree again: since you will not obtain what you want through the constriction with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not necessary that there be less than a finger between one star and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the sick person is injured by the points of the stars after the constriction in healthy places: then place beneath them from soft wool or carmine-coated wool, until nothing is injured from that.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a break with a wound, and there is a rupture on the skin, I shall come for its reminder in Chapter 2 under special circumstances.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken limb should be strung with stars from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 For since a limb is large when it is large, you should not place stars on top of it unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the coming of a hot apoplectic fit.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 This is the method of ointments, which the ancients used to place on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 Common Ointment Method, restoring a fracture, suitable for many temperaments, especially women and children, since it is from that which heat does not conquer nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And you should receive from the flour mill dust, and it is the marrow of wheat that hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the millstone: and make it as such, except that you sieve it with egg white: and place the mixture not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another Ointment Method, restoring a fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Prepare a paste with almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath. Grind all of them together with ten parts of myrrh, five parts of aloes, and twenty parts of althea. Strain the mixture and sift it. Mix it with water of althea, or with sheep's milk whey if the patient's complexion is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Use this paste as a plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, restores broken bones quickly, and is beneficial for many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of applying a plaster, which also helps with fractures and dislocations.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Prepare mugath, mess, white althea, all ground together with ten parts of myrrh, five parts of aloes, six parts of acacia, twenty parts of Armenian clay, and grind them thoroughly, sift them, and make into a paste with water or sheep's milk whey. Administer it.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of applying a plaster for joints that are dislocated and bones separated from their places: it soothes the pain, heals the broken bone, and stops the cracking.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take boiled wool, immerse it in vinegar and heated oil, and place it on the affected area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 In this plaster, there is no power of restoration, but it is good for the soothing of a hot abscess and for expelling specific pains.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Another method of applying a plaster that restores broken bones.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take the leaves of fig tree and wild papaver, grind them all, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Another method of applying a short-term plaster for the restoration of broken bones and when you want to dissolve the remnants of an abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Prepare the root of althea, chamomile, marsh marigold flowers, and the flour of herbs, all in equal parts. Grind them all and make into a paste with wine if the affected area is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated, then prepare it with water of coriander steeped in water, or use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method for resolving an abscess, which is stronger than the first, when a hard abscess occurs during the healing of a limb.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Take the root of althea, linseed seed, balustia, lentil, samsuc, violets, camomile and mix them all together, grind each part into one, then prepare it with water of willow or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply the whole thing according to the heat of the limb, and the calmness of its warmth.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates however did not say in his book that it should be placed on a broken limb during its healing, except for wax made from tallow and oil; not anything else; and he said that it should be of medium thickness between coarseness and fineness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galen however considered it appropriate to place on a broken limb during its healing substances that have the property of extracting heat, such as myrrh, aloes and frankincense and similar substances from what we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method of plaster that helps with injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Take mugath, chickpeas, human hair cuttings or bird feathers, althea, and salt in equal parts: grind them, sift them, and prepare plaster from it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The quantity that should remain as ligature is such that you consider whether pain does not occur, nor itching, nor the bone moves from its place; then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If there is intense itching, restless pain, or swelling at the site; then hurry and dissolve it within an hour, remove the plaster from it; and take a soft cloth or sea sponge, moistened with warm water and clean the place with it until the itching subsides and the pain settles.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the member rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place upon it a woolen cloth soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it at night until you are certain of the absence of the hot inflammation, and let the swelling of the member subside, and remove the pain from it.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeatedly apply it to a narrow bandage and small plaster: and do not bind it with your first constriction, and with fine ones until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all other signs have been completely removed: then apply the plaster and bandage equally as you did at first.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of the aforementioned occurs in the member: then do not loosen it until three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is released after twenty days, according to what you see in the solution of the member, as we have said: until such time as the fracture adheres and coagulation of flesh over it: add also more to your bandage than your first bandage: and add also more nourishment for the weak, according to the memory of its previous condition.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see that the location of the fracture is already drying out and becoming too thin: then know that nourishment must not reach it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Therefore pour warm water on it at every place where you loosen it: and let it be for all three days, and alleviate the bandage slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 Therefore by this operation nourishment flows to the member, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 However what stupid restorers do for a fracture of the member instead of restoration as it should be: when it is not restored first according to necessity, and restored according to twists: it is an error from their operation, and great fear: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said that in their books, and they would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have not seen any trace of theirs there at all, and it is better that it is not done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 On the making of an ulcer in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 The types of fractures are various, and their shapes are many; and their causes are separate.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For from a fracture is that which occurs from a blow with a sword; and the blow removes the bone completely as far as it reaches to the pia mater, which is under the bone, just as an axe does in wood; and because of this, this type of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 The knife has cut something of a bone and has cut its face, but it does not pierce through the incision to the end of it; and this type of fracture is called Kalaman, that is, Absolute Lever.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And it is a wound of two types of fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from the fracture is that which is a crush or rubbing; and its cause is striking with a stone, or falling upon a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also piercing, which approaches the cloth that is under the bone; or it is on the face of the bone; and it is a wound of these two types of fractures, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from the fracture is that which is hidden within the bone in the subtlety of hair; and it is a small crack, and because of this it is called this type of fracture Capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And from them is a fracture which occurs from falling or striking with a stone and similar things, which cause the lamina of the bone to enter into the interior; and it forms a hollow: as happens with cauldrons of brass, when they are struck and part of them enters into the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 And it often occurs in the moist skull bones, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these types of fractures are separated by sawing, and I will go with the reminder of the entire thing to its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 And we recognize all these types of fractures by examination on it and investigation of them with probes, and removal of the rotten flesh that is over them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 But the Capillary type is recognized by this: it is exposed on the bone and scraped off, and rubbed upon it with a hot iron; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In treating a fracture, consider first the condition of the sick man; then if you see from his conditions that it indicates fear clearly, as vomiting cholera, extension, loss of intellect, abscission of voice, fainting, acute fever, discharge of eyes, redness of them and similar things in many dispositions, without a doubt he will not be cured; and if you see conditions that do not frighten you and you hope for salvation; then begin the treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If a wounded person comes to you first with a wound, and it is during the days of winter, then it is necessary that you should study in the removal of the bone before the fourteenth day according to every arrangement.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 If it is during the days of summer, then you should hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is beneath the bone decays from fat and such things as we have mentioned happen.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of the bone has already reached the fat touching the brain and is with fragments and traction, then you should cut the fragmented and smoothed part according to what I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded and pierce through the bone according to whatever method is possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound and what is light on what is weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If there occurs to you during the piercing of the bone a flow of blood or a hot abscess, then apply what is necessary to it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is necessary that you fill the place with soaked cloths in wine and rose oil: and let the wound rest until the abscess settles down and you are secure from the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the healing of the bone, and removal of it.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is to cut the bone with a knife with a narrow blade: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another knife wider than the first: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then administer yet another knife wider still.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is that you have a number of knives of various sizes, some of which are wider than others and some of which are shorter than others: and they should be at the end points of their sharpening, and made of iron or hardened: and use them with ease in striking the knife, so as not to shake the head and hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard and tough: then it is necessary that you perforate around its circumference before you administer Incisoria, with Terebris which are called Terebra not penetrating deep: and they are not named thus unless because they do not penetrate beyond the bone marrow to what lies after it; therefore, because the tip of the Terebra is rounded above that which is under its head sharp, similar to an edge, and a small circle prevents submerging, and penetrating through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 It is necessary that you take a great number of these Terebris, one of which should correspond to the thickness of the bone; until the present has all the Terebrum of the skull: whose sharp tip's quantity in length and breadth should be according to the thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three types of Terebris or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of perforating around the bone that is broken, is: that you place the Terebra on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then exchange the Terebra to another place and place what is between every hole of a size equal to the thickness of a finger or about it.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with Incisoria what is between every hole from the bone: and do it more subtle than possible over that from the end of delicacy, as we said, until you have removed the bone, either by your hand or with some other tools which you have prepared for this; such as tenalias and delicate forpices.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary that you be careful with all caution, that the Terebra or Incisoria touches nothing from silk.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you perforate the bone by going around and it is separated from silk, if it was continuous with it, and you remove it, it is necessary that you shave, and equalize the remaining part in the bone with another similar Incisoria.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 It is necessary that it should be thin and subtle more than other incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains from small bones and cartilage, then take it with ease, with what is near you among your tools.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound after that with linen, and the ointments that I mentioned.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of operation is easy, completely distant from fear; which Galen said and praised greatly; and this is his statement.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 You must first begin to expose a piece of bone from the place where the fracture is more violent and clear; until when you have exposed that part and placed under it the tip of this Convex Incisor, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The convex part does not cut anything; and the sharp part of it extends on both sides in length, as you see; so that the convex part may be attached to the splint, with its face incidentally sharp on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike the Convex Incisor on one side with a small hammer until you cut all the bone with ease, as it is rotated; and you will be safe from the cloth that does not fall into the place you fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the doctor were not foolish among men, and more ignorant of this, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the cloth in some places, he would cut it off with the tip of the Convex Incisor and free it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone fracture does not penetrate to the cloth and what is cut away from the bone is its face, and roughness and subtle cartilage remains in it; then it is necessary that you remove the roughness, and dig out the cartilages with finer rasors that you have prepared of various sizes, so that it will be possible for you to administer them in every place more suitable and correct according to where the operation leads you, and the fractured bone, and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 It is necessary that you administer [the procedure] according to your reasoning, firstly cutting the bone more widely with those broader scalpels.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer instrument after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 Keep doing that continuously until you reach administering it more thinly and more finely with them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each of the remaining small cracks and subtle fractures, it is necessary that you administer care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a thing that does not hide upon every one who has any study in this art and it stands upon what we have written and shown in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If however a piece of flesh is detected while you are cutting the bone: then it is necessary that you take linen cloth according to the size of the wound and immerse it in rose oil and place it over the wound opening.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another cloth doubled or tripled and immerse it in wine and rose oil and place it on top of the first one: and do that as easily as possible over it so that it is not too heavy.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer a wide bandage over it and do not tie it except according to the amount that holds the wound only: and leave it with this care for one day or two days until you are certain about hot swelling.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it and administer afterwards medications with which excessive dryness is necessary: such as the roots of garlic, flour of herbs, powder of frankincense, Aristolochia, and similar ones: and it is so that you make a powder from these medications and sprinkle it over the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And administer universally in that all medication with a property to cleanse and not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 Be careful according to your virtue, so that the wound may be clean during your treatment: neither should there be dirt from ointment, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Do not let pus gather at all on it, because when pus gathers upon the brain tissue, it corrupts it and putrefies it, and a great evil happens after that to the sick person: and already has happened on the skull, when the bone is cleaned by him, especially when the care of it is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore, if the afflictions that have been mentioned occur to the sick person, know that it is certainly dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 And if the blackness does not occur, except from the medicine that is put upon him, and it is in the virtue of that medicine to make the blackness: then you should receive a part from honey, three parts from rose oil, and wash with them cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it upon the skull: afterwards take care of it with suitable remedies for healing, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of a broken nose.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except for two of its upper parts at once, or one of them: because it has two bones, since below it is cartilaginous and does not break, nor does it happen to it except by abrasion, curvature, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of its two parts is broken, then you should insert a small finger into the nose's opening and align the fracture with your index finger and thumb on the outside until the nose returns to its natural shape: and do this skillfully with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And be careful that pain does not occur upon the sick person due to your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose, and it is not reached by the finger: then it is necessary to equalize the end of the radius, where there is a small swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture occurs in two parts, then do as follows: and approach with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, at rest, let the aposteme be made with warm poultices.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of linen cloth into the end of the nose, if the fracture is in one part: or insert two pieces of linen cloth if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be in the cloth a swelling of such size that it fills the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some old restorers said that they should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But this does not seem to me, on the contrary, it is necessary that the linen cloth should be soaked in egg white, made with flour mill.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then release the linen cloth until the bone hardens and the cartilage thickens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a feather of a goose is inserted into the nose instead of the linen cloth, after it has been covered with soft fabric: and this happens so that the feather tightly holds the fracture of the nose, and prevents the weak from being hindered in breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you wish, do it: and if you wish, do with linen cloth.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose again becomes infected while performing an aposteme with warm poultices, plaster the nose with pitch or with copper pledget soaked in rose oil or a little with tannin.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if there is no infection of the warm poultice, then it is necessary to plaster it with wheat flour and frankincense powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft cloth upon it (the wound), and do not bind the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If the nasal bones are broken into pieces, or crushed, then it is necessary that you make an incision over them and extract those pieces using suitable instruments for the purpose.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then make a suture (stitch), and care for it with what coagulates (the tissue) and consolidates it using suitable ointments or poultices that are suitable for the purpose.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If it happens (that) there is a wound between the nose, then it is necessary to care for it with linen and administer a lead cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when it breaks.
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw breaks and there is no wound associated with it: examine whether its break is only external and not broken into two, and if it bends inwardly: then its diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the break is on the right side of the jaw, insert your left index finger into the sick person's mouth: similarly, if the break is on the left jaw, then insert your right index finger: and press with it the bulge of the fracture inwardly towards the outside with your other hand from the inner part of the bone evenly, and with it align it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the break of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then you must administer an extension from both parts according to their alignment: until it is possible for them to be aligned evenly.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If it happens that there is movement or dislocation of the teeth, then bind those that you hope will remain with a wire made of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place soft wax on the broken jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place over it a double cloth, and place upon the cloth a large awl well made: or a piece of shoeleather equal in length to the jawbone.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above as your preparation of the ligature requires and its application suits until it does not destroy itself: and order the sick one to take it quietly and with calmness: and place for him soft food for eating.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you judge that it changes in some way by any means: then hurry and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then straighten out what is twisted from it, and plaster it with a plaster made of milled flour with egg white or with wheat bran after removing the soot: and place upon the plaster a soft woolen cloth.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 As long as that plaster remains attached to it and the bone's position does not change, leave it undisturbed until it heals: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 For this fracture is frequently bound in three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If a hot abscess occurs meanwhile, then administer what we have said many times for the soothing of it until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if the fracture is with a wound, be aware.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If the fragment is separated from the bone or a tooth, be careful. Then use subtlety to remove those fragments of the gum that suit you for their removal using instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the opening of the wound is narrowed, then enlarge it with a leech according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the gum, and nothing remains from it, or if the opening of the wound is large: and if not, place upon it an ointment that suits for that purpose, and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 On the restoration of a broken Fork (Furcula).
Caput VI.	 Head VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 Much indeed breaks the Fork from the anterior part near the shoulder, and its fracture is made according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Either it breaks into two parts, beyond which occur protrusions (satagiae); and it is easier to restore this fracture.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 The translation is: "It is thus, what happens in a fractured bone: and it is more difficult for restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 The translation is: "It is thus, what is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 The translation is: "And the operation in this case when there is no wound, it is to make present two assistants, so that one of them holds the supporting lever (Furcula) which follows the fracture, and the other stretches the neck towards the opposite side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 The translation is: "Then, make an equal fracture with your fingers until it has the required shape: and there should not be any projection nor depression.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 The translation is: "If you need more extension, then it is necessary to place under the weak person's pillow a sphere made of cloth or wool, and let its size be according to your necessity: and extend, lift the lever, and press the sphere with your hand until an equal fracture, as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 The translation is: "If you cannot pull the end of the lever outwards because it has reached deep inside: then, let the weak person lie on their neck and place a small plank under their shoulder in size, and press the assistant's arm downwards until the bone of the lever that is deep inside is lifted up to the surface: and then correct the fracture and make an equal one with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 The translation is: "If you feel a spasm from the lever and it moves: then, press on it and extract the spasm with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 The translation is: "If it is retained in the bone, then make an incision in that place with a tool prepared for this purpose after you have placed the instrument which holds the sifach under the lever. And the tool is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 The translation is: "And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 The shell that lacks a hollow.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let the width of it be according to what you need for it due to the size of the bone, and its smallness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 Its length too, if possible for you, according to the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And let it have two ends, as you see: and one end be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If, however, the fracture of the wound which you have cut when you extracted the splinter of bone is wide and you fear from a hot fistula: then bring together two lips of the wound with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the fracture is small or you fear a hot fistula: then fill the wound with rags and pulverized charcoal according to the size of the wound incision.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If, however, a hot fistula occurs: then soak the rag in rose oil, vinegar, wine and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But a bone setting without wound and without incision is as follows: place plaster made from flour milled with egg white on the bone.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place a soft woolen cloth over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere under it if you need it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take the hemorrhoid, that is, a wooden roll which Saracens hold, which should be very long: and its width should be the size of one palm, or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a double layer of charcoal on the woolen cloth and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take a small awl made from fine wood, whose width is three fingers, and similarly long.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then thrust it through the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then thrust the cloth with the awl into the place of the hemorrhoid which falls on the fracture and wound.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the hemorrhoid on the fracture as it is rolled, and thrust it into the neck of the patient, both above the healthy part and below the injured part: and bring it all over so that the setting holds the fracture tightly: and this is what should not be hidden from you, and entirely, so that the awl does not move away from the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 It is necessary to observe the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Whenever the bandage becomes soft and you see the splinter moving: then adjust it and tighten the bandage.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick person's sleep on his back and put a small pill under his pillow during sleep, so that when he awakens, help will be summoned from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Therefore, break the collarbone by elevating the shoulder joint.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind his arm to his neck and do not loosen the bandage unless it happens in the place where it is bound due to itching or abscess, for up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face turning towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add to the constriction, and release it when it is healed and congealed.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The break in the collarbone is bound and supported as much as possible for 20 days; but sometimes it occurs in a lesser degree in some people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the repair of the spatula (thoracic plate).
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 The spatula rarely breaks, and in its wide place: and it is not broken from it except for its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When the place from which it breaks and breaks in its middle is not known except by touch, then according to its shape prepare its treatment.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And bring it back to its natural form by any means of skill that is possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on it a little dust from the mill with egg white, and soft wool, and put above it a small piece of double-folded cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place on it a broad needle from thin wood according to the size of the spatula, or slightly larger but not too much.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 But if there is a depression under the needle in any part of the spatula, then fill that depression with soft wool until the needle descends to the same level.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then sew above it with long alum thread in a proper tension and the firmness of the needle until it is not moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And examine the sutures every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the suture becomes soft, sew it, and if the needle is moved from its place, let it lie weak on its healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 The spatula is restored within twenty days, or within thirty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number is completed, then dissolve the suture: and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is made from bones whose fracture is not feared, nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 But if a piece of bone protrudes and pierces the skin beneath it, then cut above it, and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we said in the treatment of the clavicle fracture by applying a hot poultice, if anything happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of chest fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Head VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 Chest sometimes breaks in the middle of itself, and it happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities break or are crushed more often due to accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.
